div.p: Greetings. I have just returned home from the countryside from my brother, who has begun to fall ill.

I found your letters but had nothing to respond with. From France, nothing new, except that the allied princes have again written to the magistrate with Condé and sent a treaty or the form of a treaty. They also sent a copy of the letters sent to Emperor Ferdinand; but they contain nothing that we have not heard before. There is a rumor, to which I give little credit, that the Elector of Saxony has sent a delegate to the council and that Maximilian has dismissed all his ministers and is going to the council to preside over it.
If this is true, the Pope's practices are indeed very powerful; if you have any certain information on this matter, please share it, I beg you. Farewell.
These things have indeed been brought from elsewhere.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Ambrosius Blarer, residing in Winterthur, esteemed lord and dearest brother. Winterthur.
